Title:
Two new species of Hyphoderma on fallen branch of angiosperm
from southern China
Keywords:
Keywords Corticioid fungi, Diversity, Hyphodermataceae,
Molecular phylogeny, Taxonomy, Yunnan Province
Abstract:
Two new wood-inhabiting fungal species, Hyphoderma
puerense and H. tenuissimum spp. nov. are proposed based on a
combination of morphological features and molecular evidence. Hyphoderma
puerense is characterized by an annual growth habit, resupinate
basidiomata with smooth to flocculent hymenial surface, a monomitic
hyphal system with generative hyphae bearing clamped connections, IKI,
CB and ellipsoid, colorless, thin-walled, smooth basidiospores measuring
as 67.5 × 34.5 µm. Hyphoderma tenuissimum is characterized by resupinate
basidiomata with tuberculate to mini-grandinoid hymenial surface, a
monomitic hyphal system, presence of septate cystidia and cylindrical to
allantoid, colorless, thin-walled, smooth basidiospores. Sequences of
ITS+nLSU nrRNA gene regions of the studied samples were generated and
phylogenetic analyses were performed with maximum likelihood, maximum
parsimony and Bayesian inference methods. These phylogenetic analyses
based on molecular data of ITS+nLSU sequences showed that two new
species clustered into Hyphoderma, in which H. puerense grouped with H.
moniliforme, and H. tenuissimum was sister to H. mopanshanense.
